ID.AM.name: Asset Management
ID.AM.description: The data, personnel, devices, systems, and facilities that enable the organization to achieve business purposes are identified and managed consistent with their relative importance to organizational objectives and the organizationâ€™s risk strategy.

ID.AM-1.description: Physical devices and systems within the organization are inventoried
recommendations: Maintain and periodically update a physical device inventory with certain data elements such as make, model, serial number, asset location, assignee, acquisition date, and decommission date. Update this inventory as assets are acquired, transferred, or decommissioned.
vulnerability_stmts: Without an accurate and complete list of physical assets across all business units, it is not possible to know if patching is happening consistently. If the organization cannot account for all endpoints and servers, some are being missed for vulnerability management and access control.

ID.AM-2.description: Software platforms and applications within the organization are inventoried
recommendations: Maintain an accurate, documented inventory of all software and applications containing PII and a process to ensure the organization is aware of new products and products that are no longer in use. The inventory should contain: system name, vendor, system type, scope of implementation, host location, type of data stored, implementation date, and termination date.
vulnerability_stmts: Without an accurate and complete list of software and platforms across all business units, it is not possible to know if patching is happening consistently. If the organization cannot account for all endpoints and servers, some are being missed for vulnerability management and access control.

ID.AM-3.description: Organizational communication and data flows are mapped
recommendations: Map data flows

Ensure that system interoperability information flows necessary to carry out organizational objectives are defined and documented as part of network diagrams. Interoperability information includes: source system, destination system, data transferred, method of transfer, and purpose.
vulnerability_stmts: Without accurate and complete documentation of data flows and communication flows, it will be impossible to accurately document all dependencies. Listing of priority and dependencies for critical systems will be incomplete.

recommendations: Maintain an accurate, documented inventory of externally hosted information systems containing PII or any sensitive information, and a process to ensure the organization is aware of new products and products that are no longer in use. The inventory should contain: system name, vendor, system type, scope of implementation, host location, type of data stored, implementation date, and termination date.
vulnerability_stmts: External information systems are not catalogued consistently. It may be difficult to identify the source of technical issues originating from outside the company relating to supply chain cybersecurity risk.

ID.AM-5.description: Resources (e.g., hardware, devices, data, time, personnel, and software) are prioritized based on their classification, criticality, and business value
recommendations: BIA

Build and periodically update a documented listing of information system classification and criticality, and ensure the characteristics of the levels within those scales are clearly defined and documented.
vulnerability_stmts: Prioritization of systems has not been formally documented. Application of defense and funding may be inappropriate or allocated to the wrong priorities.

ID.AM-6.description: Cybersecurity roles and responsibilities for the entire workforce and third-party stakeholders (e.g., suppliers, customers, partners) are established
recommendations: Build or establish as part of an existing committee clearly defined roles and responsibility to ensure cybersecurity issues are addressed and the security program is improved.

Build a security charter which establishes the security role, and identifies the requirements for maintaining a staffed security team. Document the need for continuous improvement of the security program and establish a committee to monitor performance of the program.
vulnerability_stmts: Management is not held accountable for ensuring that employees, contractors and third-party resources adhere to or enforce the organization’s information security policies and procedures responsibilities prior to being granted access to sensitive information or information systems.

Management is not held accountable for ensuring that employees, contractors and third-party resources are properly briefed on their information security roles and responsibilities prior to being granted access to sensitive information or information systems.

Without a Security Charter or other directive policy and documentation, management is not held accountable for ensuring that employees, contractors and third-party resources are required to execute and fulfill the security policies of the organization.

ID.BE.name: Business Environment
ID.BE.description: The organizationâ€™s mission, objectives, stakeholders, and activities are understood and prioritized; this information is used to inform cybersecurity roles, responsibilities, and risk management decisions.

ID.BE-1.description: The organization’s role in the supply chain is identified and communicated
recommendations: Formally define the organization's role in the supply chain, and utilize the understanding of that role to inform security operations. Clearly define stakeholders and dependencies in the organization's supply chain and build strategies accordingly.
vulnerability_stmts: Without clear direction from management on how the organization supply chain operates, cybersecurity efforts and expenditure may not support appropriate controls for stakeholders and supply chain dependencies.

ID.BE-2.description: The organization’s place in critical infrastructure and its industry sector is identified and communicated
recommendations: CISA.gov
InfraGard.org

Formally define the organization's role in critical infrastructure, and utilize the understanding of that role to inform security operations. Clearly define stakeholders and dependencies in the organization's supply chain and build strategies accordingly.
vulnerability_stmts: Without clear direction from management on how the organization supports or relies on critical infrastructure, cybersecurity efforts and expenditure may not support appropriate controls for stakeholders and supply chain dependencies.

ID.BE-3.description: Priorities for organizational mission, objectives, and activities are established and communicated
ID.BE-3.genus: Cybersecurity Objectives Aligned with Organization Objectives
recommendations: Ensure that strategic plans are communicated to all staff. Align security goals and objectives to strategic initiatives for the organization. Measure level of goal achievement periodically throughout the year.
vulnerability_stmts: Without clear direction from management on organization mission and priorities, cybersecurity efforts and expenditure may not support appropriate controls for the strategic goals of the organization.

ID.BE-4.description: Dependencies and critical functions for delivery of critical services are established
recommendations: Identify and document critical services and their supporting systems and processes. Conduct a Business Impact Analysis to ensure all supporting dependencies are mapped to their critical functions.
vulnerability_stmts: Dependencies and critical functions for delivery of critical services has not yet been formally established and documented. Priorities for response during a cyber incident may be inappropriate or misplaced.

ID.BE-5.description: Resilience requirements to support delivery of critical services are established for all operating states (e.g. under duress/attack, during recovery, normal operations)
recommendations: Identify resilience requirements of critical services through the use of clear and defined categories. Review and update categories consistently as the organizational environment, requirements, or technology change. Use tiers of importance to guide implementation of resilience requirements (Tier 0, 1, 2, 3, gold, silver, bronze, etc.). Consider and document a process of reacting to how different operating states (e.g. under duress/attack, during recovery, normal operation) may impact the priority of resilience/recovery of each system in relation to other systems in the organization.
vulnerability_stmts: Dependencies and critical functions for delivery of critical services has not yet been formally established and documented. Priorities for resilience and recovery of systems during a cyber incident may be inappropriate or misplaced.

ID.GV.name: Governance
ID.GV.description: The policies, procedures, and processes to manage and monitor the organizationâ€™s regulatory, legal, risk, environmental, and operational requirements are understood and inform the management of cybersecurity risk.

ID.GV-1.description: Organizational cybersecurity policy is established and communicated
recommendations: Establish an organizational information security policy reflecting appropriate laws, regulations, and

policies. Communicate the policy to end users and train them how best comply with its guidance and rules. The policy should be updated consistently as the organizational environment, requirements, or technology change.
vulnerability_stmts: Without a Security Charter or other directive policy and documentation, management is not held accountable for ensuring that employees, contractors, and third-party resources are required to execute and fulfill the security policies of the organization. The strategy and execution of the information security program will not follow any standard of practice or organization goals.

ID.GV-2.description: Cybersecurity roles and responsibilities are coordinated and aligned with internal roles and external partners
recommendations: Ensure that cybersecurity roles and responsibilities are defined and documented, and those responsibilities are aligned with the roles of the appropriate staff members or external partners. Integrate the allocation of cybersecurity roles into the process of planning for critical changes to the environment.
vulnerability_stmts: Responsibilities for the protection of individual assets and for carrying out specific information security processes have not been identified. As a result, information security controls are not implemented in a consistent or sustainable manner. Information security responsibilities will not be aligned to strategically support internal or external partners and stakeholders.

ID.GV-3.description: Legal and regulatory requirements regarding cybersecurity, including privacy and civil liberties obligations, are understood and managed
recommendations: Identify, communicate, and train end-users on legal and regulatory requirements so they are well understood at all levels of the organization and are used to define the organization's data security practices.
vulnerability_stmts: Without an inventory of legal, regulatory, and client requirements or obligations, the information security program may not cover important controls. Additionally, prioritization of information security budget, time, and other resources may be inappropriate to achieve compliance with the required obligations.
"You can't prioritize and comply with controls that you don't know are required."

ID.GV-4.description: Governance and risk management processes address cybersecurity risks
recommendations: Define the organization's appetite for risk, identify where cybersecurity risks exist, assign severity to those risks, and use that knowledge to inform prioritized action plans related to risk treatment (remediation, mitigation, avoidance, transference, acceptance).
vulnerability_stmts: Without a complete, documented governance and risk management process information security risks may not be prioritized appropriately for remediation. This lack of governance leads to stagnation and ultimately the impotence or inability to take effective action of the information security program.

ID.RA.name: Risk Assessment
ID.RA.description: The organization understands the cybersecurity risk to organizational operations (including mission, functions, image, or reputation), organizational assets, and individuals.

ID.RA-1.description: Asset vulnerabilities are identified and documented
recommendations: Identify asset vulnerabilities using manual processes and automated vulnerability scanning tools. Verify results with periodic external vulnerability assessments.
vulnerability_stmts: Information security controls will not prioritized to remediate gaps if the organization does not know the gaps exist.
"You can't fix what you don't know is broke."

ID.RA-2.description: Cyber threat intelligence is received from information sharing forums and sources
recommendations: Subscribe to threat and vulnerability updates from reputable organizations and use the information to enhance security practices.
vulnerability_stmts: An information security program will grow stagnant and ineffective without constant updates on threats and other vulnerability intelligence from an active cybersecurity community.

ID.RA-3.description: Threats, both internal and external, are identified and documented
recommendations: Ensure that cybersecurity threats to the organization are identified, documented, and understood, and are verified via external threat assessments. These threats will likely be unique to the organization in some cases. Use a threat matrix to document threats in an organized and informative format.
vulnerability_stmts: Information security strategy will lack the realism of a customized threat profile without a comprehensive evaluation of the threats the organization truly faces. A well researched threat profile should inform direction and strategy for the cybersecurity program of the organization.

ID.RA-4.description: Potential business impacts and likelihoods are identified
recommendations: Identify and document the impact and likelihood of vulnerability exploitations to the organization.
Use a Business Impact Analysis to align impact and criticality information to cybersecurity initiatives with a risk register.
vulnerability_stmts: In the absence of a thorough business impact analysis linked to vulnerability analysis results,  information security initiatives will not be aligned and prioritized appropriately with criticality and impact information.

ID.RA-5.description: Threats, vulnerabilities, likelihoods, and impacts are used to determine risk
recommendations: Use a threat matrix, vulnerability analysis, and a business impact analysis to build a comprehensive Risk Registry which is informed by threats, vulnerabilities, likelihoods, and impacts. Use the risk rankings in the risk registry to prioritize work and guide decisions on how to treat risk.
vulnerability_stmts: In the absence of a thorough business impact analysis linked to vulnerability analysis results, information security initiatives and other risk mitigation will not be aligned and prioritized appropriately with criticality and impact information.

ID.RA-6.description: Risk responses are identified and prioritized
recommendations: Identify where cybersecurity risks exist and develop action plans to treat those risks. Choose treatment options to reduce the risk to acceptable levels based on a defined risk appetite and the severity of each risk.
Define and document the treatment options available to the organization. Establish criteria for how each treatment option aligns with levels of risk severity.
vulnerability_stmts: Without direction from management and accountability for implementation of controls, risk responses may not be prioritized appropriately. Information security expenditure may not align with the risk appetite of the organization.

ID.RM.name: Risk Management Strategy
ID.RM.description: The organizationâ€™s priorities, constraints, risk tolerances, and assumptions are established and used to support operational risk decisions.

ID.RM-1.description: Risk management processes are established, managed, and agreed to by organizational stakeholders
recommendations: Establish a committee to define, document, and manage organizational information security risks through a documented process of assessing and treating risk. Committee members should represent all critical areas of organizational operations in order to accurately identify risks and their effects on the organization as a whole. Risk findings should be regularly assessed via external risk assessment experts.
vulnerability_stmts: Siloed efforts to reduce risk may make small improvements in treating specific areas of risk. However, without a cross-functional group made up of members of management, the organization may miss opportunities to identify and represent risk treatment needs in all areas of the operating environment.

ID.RM-2.description: Organizational risk tolerance is determined and clearly expressed
recommendations: Along with representation from each department, define the organization’s tolerance for information security risks. This definition should come from a committee with representation from all critical areas of the organization.
vulnerability_stmts: Without clear guidance from management on which risks to treat, the information security efforts of the organization may be prioritized inappropriately.

ID.RM-3.description: The organization’s determination of risk tolerance is informed by its role in critical infrastructure and sector specific risk analysis
recommendations: Ensure that the organization's determination of risk tolerance includes analysis of its role in critical infrastructure. The impact of risk should be informed by dependencies and external stakeholders (i.e. citizens, other agencies, etc.).
vulnerability_stmts: Without a clear understanding of the inherent risk in the type of product or service the organization offers, risk treatment may not be properly prioritized.

ID.SC.name: Supply Chain Risk Management
ID.SC.description: The organizationâ€™s priorities, constraints, risk tolerances, and assumptions are established and used to support risk decisions associated with managing supply chain risk. The organization has established and implemented the processes to identify, assess and manage supply chain risks.

ID.SC-1.description: Cyber supply chain risk management processes are identified, established, assessed, managed, and agreed to by organizational stakeholders
recommendations: Ensure that risks incurred by utilizing information systems designed or hosted by external entities, are included in risk management discussions. A representative committee should be responsible for assessing and treating supply chain risk.
vulnerability_stmts: The cyber supply chain risk management program may not receive appropriate support and direction without the establishment of the program by the leaders and other key stakeholders of the organization. A gap in this support may lead to supply chain risk not being identified and treated.

ID.SC-2.description: Suppliers and third party partners of information systems, components, and services are identified, prioritized, and assessed using a cyber supply chain risk assessment process
recommendations: Establish a process to identify and evaluate risks associated with third-party information systems and service, prior to their use by the organization. Include input from all critical areas of the organization.
vulnerability_stmts: The organization does not perform a formal risk assessment including business criticality or value of information involved, from utilizing or granting access to 3rd party resources, contractors, or other external parties. If the process to identify and assess cyber supply chain risk is not established, major risks to the organization may go unnoticed and untreated.

ID.SC-3.description: Contracts with suppliers and third-party partners are used to implement appropriate measures designed to meet the objectives of an organization’s cybersecurity program and Cyber Supply Chain Risk Management Plan.
recommendations: Establish a process to assess contracts with third-party partners (especially those who access any sensitive or personally identifiable information) and ensure that they meet organizational security and privacy requirements.
vulnerability_stmts: A lack of contract language regarding shared accountability or responsibility for implementing appropriate cyber security measures may lead inappropriate use of information or systems.

ID.SC-4.description: Suppliers and third-party partners are routinely assessed using audits, test results, or other forms of evaluations to confirm they are meeting their contractual obligations.
recommendations: Periodically re-evaluate contracts with third-party partners who access any organizational information, to ensure they continue to meet organizational security and privacy requirements.
Work with critical vendors to request results of audits, testing, or other assessments to demonstrate that they are meeting contractual obligations.
vulnerability_stmts: The regular review of supply chain partners is not in place. This may lead to unnoticed and untreated risk to internal systems and information.

ID.SC-5.description: Response and recovery planning and testing are conducted with suppliers and third-party providers
recommendations: Request annual assurances that response and recovery processes related to important information systems, managed by third-party partners, are functional and effective.
If available, participate in simulated response and recovery activities with partners who manage critical systems.
vulnerability_stmts: Without assurance and testing of avialability and capability to respond, critical suppliers and partners may not be able to support the organization during incidents or disasters.

PR.AC.name: Identity Management, Authentication and Access Control
PR.AC.description: Access to physical and logical assets and associated facilities is limited to authorized users, processes, and devices, and is managed consistent with the assessed risk of unauthorized access to authorized activities and transactions.

PR.AC-1.description: Identities and credentials are issued, managed, verified, revoked, and audited for authorized devices, users and processes
recommendations: Implement MFA and strong passwords for Facebook/Instagram and other externally facing systems or critical systems.

Establish a process and technical capability for credential management to be performed through a single centralized mechanism (such as single-sign on technology) that creates and deactivates accounts in all information systems through an automated process.

Formal authorization and de-authorization processes should include: guidelines for system access, formal account provisioning notification, determination of access level, and formal deprovisioning notification. At any time, the organization should be able to produce accurate lists of all users with access to individual information systems.
vulnerability_stmts: Without a defined and documented identity management practice, accounts will not be protected appropriately and access to systems will not be granted in a controlled or consistent manner. This will lead to an environment which allows an attacker to have easier access to systems and data.

PR.AC-2.description: Physical access to assets is managed and protected
recommendations: Install badge access and cameras for highly sensitive areas (server rooms, data closets)

Physical access to high-value systems, sensitive information, or critical infrastructure should be restricted and monitored. Systems should reside in an isolated environment suitable to ensuring they are able to operate optimally. Restriction should include limiting direct access by physical barriers such as locked doors or locked cages only accessible by those whose responsibilities include maintaining the equipment. Monitoring should include human or automated surveillance of the area. All access should be logged by recording the accessing individual, time of access, and reason for access.
vulnerability_stmts: Lack of restriction and monitoring of physical systems and sensitive areas leaves an opportunity for an attacker or malicious insider to cause damage.

recommendations: Ensure that remote access to information systems and the organizational network is restricted to only those individuals whose job duties require remote access and the organization is able to identify the specific individual accessing the system or network. Each account should be identified and documented with the purpose for which access is needed, including temporary access accounts. Deactivate temporary accounts upon completion of the identified purpose. Use automated mechanisms to detect unauthorized activity and automatically terminate the connection.
vulnerability_stmts: When remote access is not managed and restricted to only roles that require it, the organization's attack surface and risk is greatly increased.

PR.AC-4.description: Access permissions and authorizations are managed, incorporating the principles of least privilege and separation of duties
recommendations: Assign and document access permissions in accordance with job responsibilities. Only grant access permissions to information systems as required to perform necessary duties. Regularly review and modify permissions to reflect changes in personnel, job duties, roles, and software features.
vulnerability_stmts: Unmanaged access permissions and privileges can lead to excessive privileges and broadens the opportunities an attacker can use to cause harm. Excessive privileges also leads to costly mistakes and accidental information disclosure.

PR.AC-5.description: Network integrity is protected (e.g., network segregation, network segmentation)
recommendations: Appropriately segment networks to separate traffic from individual organizational groups, departments, or networks. Use the segmentation to prevent these networks from directly interacting with each other. Ensure that users and data on low privileged networks (networks used to facilitate basic network functions, such as guest internet access), are unable to interact with higher-privileged networks. Use flow control and monitoring tools to identify and inspect traffic traveling between networks and alert system administrators to potential incidents.
vulnerability_stmts: Networks without segmentation or segregation make the step of pivoting to additional systems very easy for an attacker. This can also lead to accidental harm to the overall protection of some systems by implementing changes which are not restricted to specific security domains.

PR.AC-6.description: Identities are proofed and bound to credentials and asserted in interactions
recommendations: Utilize an Identity and Access Management solution to uniquely identify and authenticate organizational users to information systems.
Centralized IDAM tool
vulnerability_stmts: Nonrepudiation and investigations into attacks or malicious activity becomes difficult or impossible if the organization cannot prove that the account being investigated is tied to a specific person. Shared use accounts and generic accounts make investigation and attribution of criminal activity impossible.

PR.AC-7.description: Users, devices, and other assets are authenticated (e.g., single-factor, multi-factor) commensurate with the risk of the transaction (e.g., individuals’ security and privacy risks and other organizational risks)
recommendations: Use multi-factor authentication on remote connections into the organizational network, to externally accessible systems containing high-value data, and to all critical infrastructure accounts with high levels of privilege (ex. Active Directory Domain Administrator).
Strengthen password requirements for sensitive systems and implement MFA. Use passphrases instead of passwords and increase the minimum length requirements.
vulnerability_stmts: If passwords are the only mechanisms protecting access through accounts, attackers may have a much easier job gaining access to systems and information.

PR.AT.name: Awareness and Training
PR.AT.description: The organizationâ€™s personnel and partners are provided cybersecurity awareness education and are trained to perform their cybersecurity-related duties and responsibilities consistent with related policies, procedures, and agreements.

PR.AT-1.description: All users are informed and trained
recommendations: Require general security awareness and organizational policy training for all employees. Use frequent communication and smaller training modules to refresh topics multiple times throughout the year.
Deliver or procure targeted training specific to staff
members’ individual roles and responsibilities. Specific focus should be placed on areas of highest risk, for example phishing recognition.
vulnerability_stmts: If users are unaware or untrained, costly mistakes could be made and major damage to the organization could be the result. An untrained and unaware user is easier to trick in phishing schemes and other social engineering attacks.

PR.AT-2.description: Privileged users understand their roles and responsibilities
recommendations: Require annual professional development, focused on updating security skills and best practices for all privileged users. Encourage privileged users to consult with outside colleagues and specialists through information sharing groups, seminars, and conferences related to best practices.
vulnerability_stmts: Privileged users have the highest level of access inside systems and to data. They tend to be a more lucrative target for attackers. If these users are not trained and aware of potential attacks against them, they may fall victim to spear phishing or other advanced social engineering attacks. Privileged users are also responsible for implementing controls for the organization. If they are untrained, they may implement controls in an unappropriate or unprioritized way.

PR.AT-3.description: Third-party stakeholders (e.g., suppliers, customers, partners) understand their roles and responsibilities
recommendations: Define and document roles and responsibilities for third-party stakeholders. Clearly communicate to and regularly hold discussions with stakeholder groups to re-affirm and collectively refine roles and responsibilities.
vulnerability_stmts: Upstream and downstream dependencies in the supply chain organizations for an enterprise can have an impact on the security controls for the enterprise. If roles and responsibilities are not clearly defined for third-party stakeholders, security and risk for all involved organizations may be impacted.

PR.AT-4.description: Senior executives understand their roles and responsibilities
recommendations: Train executives on the role they will need to fill during cyber security incident response activities. Implement annual targeted executive security training for all executive users and ensure it is refreshed multiple times throughout the year using executive briefings and table-top exercises.
vulnerability_stmts: If management of the organization are not aware of their responsibilities pertaining to the cyber security program, they will likely not provide appropriate support to ensure that the security program will be successful in achieving the goals of the organization.

PR.AT-5.description: Physical and cybersecurity personnel understand their roles and responsibilities
recommendations: Require annual professional development, focused on updating security skills and best practices for all cybersecurity personnel. Encourage privileged users to consult with outside colleagues and specialists through information sharing groups, seminars, and conferences related to best practices.
vulnerability_stmts: If cyber security personnel are not keeping their skills and knowledge fresh with regular focused training, they may miss potential advancements in theory and application within the cyber security industry. If management doesn't support regular training for these personnel, the security program may grow stagnate and ineffective.

PR.DS.name: Data Security
PR.DS.description: Information and records (data) are managed consistent with the organizationâ€™s risk strategy to protect the confidentiality, integrity, and availability of information.

recommendations: Deploy and monitor security protections to protect infrastructure and file systems containing sensitive information from unauthorized access. Some example

mechanisms may include: firewalls, intrusion prevention systems (IPS), authentication management systems, unstructured data monitoring, filtering, white/blacklisting, and similar preventative technologies.
Employ encryption on devices containing sensitive information and devices at risk of physical theft such as removable media, mobile devices, laptops, and similar devices.
Mobile Device Management
vulnerability_stmts: Without a defined and planned approach to identify and protect data where it is stored, the organization may not have appropriate security controls in place to stop data leaks or exposures.

recommendations: Deploy encryption to protect sensitive data when

traveling from a higher security environment to a lower security environment (ex. data traveling from an internal network to the internet). Define criteria and restrictions for accessing sensitive information from outside the controlled organization environment. Some areas may include: location of access, system requirements, network security levels, and other criteria determined by the organization.
vulnerability_stmts: Without a defined and planned approach to identify and protect data as it is transferred between systems, the organization may not have appropriate security controls in place to stop data leaks or exposures.

PR.DS-3.description: Assets are formally managed throughout removal, transfers, and disposition
recommendations: Update inventory to reflect newly acquired and decommissioned assets, and the location of the asset. Track the staff to whom the asset is assigned throughout the life of the asset. Take appropriate steps  to identify and sanitize assets containing sensitive information upon decommission.
vulnerability_stmts: An inadequate asset management program often misses inventory changes during removals or transfers. This can lead to loss of control of key devices and potentially expose any data left on a device.

PR.DS-4.description: Adequate capacity to ensure availability is maintained
recommendations: Define and document capacity and availability requirements. Ensure equipment capacity, replacement cycles, staff and other necessary resources, are in place to support system availability and are sufficient to consistently meet the defined availability requirements of critical information systems.
vulnerability_stmts: Gaps in capacity planning can lead to operational impact and downtime for critical systems. Without adequate planning, critical systems or functions may exceed the available resources resulting in failure to deliver core functionality.

PR.DS-5.description: Protections against data leaks are implemented
recommendations: Define appropriate sensitivity classification levels for information and define criteria for the utilization of data within the individual classifications. Evaluate any information disseminated to individuals with lower access privileges to information and apply appropriate disclosure avoidance techniques such as redaction, blurring, perturbation, summarization, and similar techniques.
vulnerability_stmts: Without Data Loss Prevention processes or technology, the organization may not detect when sensitive data is stolen. An understanding of location, types, and sensitivity of data is critical for the success of a data leak prevention program.

PR.DS-6.description: Integrity checking mechanisms are used to verify software, firmware, and information integrity
recommendations: Apply basic integrity checking mechanisms, for example pre-boot protection tools and malware protection technologies.
Firmware inventory
Conditional access based on security baseline scan
vulnerability_stmts: Devoid of mechanisms to protect and track the integrity or accuracy of software, firmware, and information the organization will be susceptible to attacks that make use of the supply chain trust in those resources.
Firmware can be used to launch or implement attacks if it is not kept in a trusted state.
Without software integrity checking, software can be modified to take advantage of anti-malware trust of signed software.

PR.DS-7.description: The development and testing environment(s) are separate from the production environment
recommendations: Ensure that system development and testing occur within defined environments that are entirely segregated from production environments. Define a process to update the production environment with major changes or tested configuration updates.
vulnerability_stmts: When production and test systems or data are comingled, production data can be corrupted by mixing it with test data. Dedicated testing environments provide a place to verify system functionality without worrying about live data. If access to production data is not restricted, developers may accidentally or maliciously corrupt data. Only specific system administrators should have access to production data.

PR.DS-8.description: Integrity checking mechanisms are used to verify hardware integrity
recommendations: Define and document a hardware procurement and deployment process by which purchases of critical hardware and equipment are only from established, reputable sources. Prior to the installation of critical components, the hardware is examined for signs of tampering such as physical damage, missing screws, broken tamper-protection stickers, etc. Additionally, any hardware maintenance on critical equipment or replacement of failed components is monitored and logged.
vulnerability_stmts: Hardware vulnerabilities are harder to detect and require specialized knowledge. If unauthorized vendors or suppliers are used for hardware procurement, hardware enabled back doors to systems may be introduced without knowledge of the organization.

PR.IP.name: Information Protection Processes and Procedures
PR.IP.description: Security policies (that address purpose, scope, roles, responsibilities, management commitment, and coordination among organizational entities), processes, and procedures are maintained and used to manage protection of information systems and assets.

PR.IP-1.description: A baseline configuration of information technology/industrial control systems is created and maintained incorporating security principles (e.g. concept of least functionality)
recommendations: Define and document baseline configurations for all systems that include component specifications for all aspects of an information system, build and version requirements, essential ports and services, and logical placement within the organizational environment. Update baseline configurations according to system, environment, technology, or requirement changes.
Use a build checklist to ensure baselines are applied consistently during the system build process.
Use a vulnerability scanner to validate baseline configurations are consistently applied to all critical systems.
vulnerability_stmts: Without an established configuration security baseline or system build standard, systems may be built and deployed in the organization with existing vulnerabilities. Additionally, security vulnerabilities may be introduced at a higher rate than can be easily managed.

PR.IP-2.description: A System Development Life Cycle to manage systems is implemented
recommendations: Ensure the process for building and maintaining systems includes security engineering and architecture principles for configurations, functionality, and build methodology.
Review contracts and provided documentation from vendors and suppliers of key systems to ensure they are incorporating security by design into their products.
vulnerability_stmts: If appropriate requirement gathering, deployment planning, testing, and decomission planning are not performed, the security and functionality of a system and its dependencies may be negatively impacted.

PR.IP-3.description: Configuration change control processes are in place
recommendations: Identify and document changes to organization information system configurations and the purpose for those changes. Prior to the changes being applied to high-value or critical systems, conduct security and system impact analyses. Review configuration changes for known issues. Notify appropriate stakeholder groups when changes will occur, and any anticipated impacts to system access, utilization, or workflows.
vulnerability_stmts: Without prior planning, testing, documented steps, approvals, and rollback plans for proposed changes to production systems, the security and functionality of a system and its dependencies may be negatively impacted.

PR.IP-4.description: Backups of information are conducted, maintained, and tested
recommendations: Back up organizational information systems regularly for defined periods and maintain backups in a manner to appropriately ensure information is able to be recovered regardless of the severity of an incident. Test backups and backup restoration procedures for high value and critical organizational information systems at defined periods.
vulnerability_stmts: If backups of information and information systems are not performed and tested, disaster recovery efforts will be limited in success.

PR.IP-5.description: Policy and regulations regarding the physical operating environment for organizational assets are met
recommendations: Equip the physical environment for information systems and components with appropriate power management and a short-term uninterruptable power supply. Implement appropriate controls to protect information systems and components against temperature, humidity, fire, and water damage. Should a catastrophic event occur, alternative hosting and operational locations should be readily available for organizational information systems.
vulnerability_stmts: Without standards for physical operating environment, assets may be deployed in areas which could cause damage from environmental factors or unauthorized access.

PR.IP-6.description: Data is destroyed according to policy
recommendations: Determine the level of sensitivity of the information stored or transmitted and apply the appropriate sanitation mechanisms commensurate with its classification prior to disposal or repurposing of equipment. Document the media sanitization and logs the date of sanitization, the classification level of the media, the sanitization techniques applied, and whether the asset was repurposed or decommissioned.
Data Classification and Governance is a prerequisite for this to be considered effective.
vulnerability_stmts: The organization may be exposed to risk of data leak due to improper handling and disposal of information or information systems.

recommendations: Make investments to the organization's security posture. Focus those investments on areas of highest risk.
Begin gathering performance metrics of protection mechanisms and processes to track improvements and report progress to stakeholders.
vulnerability_stmts: The information security program may grow stagnant and ineffective if plans to assess control effectiveness and improve the program are not prioritized.

PR.IP-8.description: Effectiveness of protection technologies is shared
recommendations: Share investments made into the organization's security posture with stakeholder groups and demonstrate how and to what level the organization’s security posture has improved. Share the targets for the organizational security posture, the gaps that exist, and resources needed to move toward defined effectiveness targets.
vulnerability_stmts: Management may not be engaged and supportive of security program initiatives if they are not appropriately informed about progress and effectiveness of existing controls and technology.

PR.IP-9.description: Response plans (Incident Response and Business Continuity) and recovery plans (Incident Recovery and Disaster Recovery) are in place and managed
recommendations: Establish individual processes to respond to and recover from cybersecurity incidents, in order to keep information and infrastructure functioning properly. These plans should define necessary roles, responsibilities, objectives, communication chains, remediation processes, and appropriate stakeholder groups. Define and collect metrics to quantify response and continuity capabilities and help identify areas for enhancement.
vulnerability_stmts: The lack of planning and testing of response and recovery plans leads to inappropriate and lengthier response and recovery events. Ultimately, this leads to increased damage and impact to the organization.

PR.IP-10.description: Response and recovery plans are tested
recommendations: Ensure that response plans are defined, and processes, procedures, communication structures and supporting technology are regularly tested to ensure the plan can function as intended. Processes, procedures, and supporting technology should be updated as the environment or requirements change, or failures occur in during plan execution. Metrics related to frequency, success, and efficiency are developed, collected, and reviewed.
vulnerability_stmts: Without testing the plans that have been built, the organization may be blind to gaps in communication or other parts of the process that may lengthen or impact efforts to restore normal operations.

PR.IP-11.description: Cybersecurity is included in human resources practices (e.g., deprovisioning, personnel screening)
recommendations: Offboarding checklist building (System list, access list, physical assets).

Incorporate cybersecurity and organizational policy training into new employee onboarding processes. System access should be identified and granted during onboarding, monitored and modified during employment, and revoked during deprovisioning. Upon termination, shared credentials, (e.g. system accounts, service accounts) to which the former employee had access, should be changed immediately. Incorporate cybersecurity evaluation into personnel screening for prospective employees and into current employee performance evaluation.
vulnerability_stmts: In the abscense of clear instructions and steps for each stage of employment and human resource management, the human element can introduce vulnerabilities to the organization.

PR.IP-12.description: A vulnerability management plan is developed and implemented
recommendations: Apply critical patches and hotfixes upon release from software vendors. Examine identified technical and process vulnerabilities, and determine what steps and resources, if any, are necessary to lower the risk profile of the vulnerability to an acceptable level.
vulnerability_stmts: Devoid of a regemented cadence of assessing, tracking, and fixing discovered vulnerabilities, the organization leaves multiple weaknesses for an attacker to use to cause damage to the organization.

PR.MA.name: Maintenance
PR.MA.description: Maintenance and repairs of industrial control and information system components are performed consistent with policies and procedures.

PR.MA-1.description: Maintenance and repair of organizational assets are performed and logged, with approved and controlled tools
recommendations: Ensure that reasons and times for maintenance of organizational assets are documented, and tools utilized are formally defined and vetted.
vulnerability_stmts: If maintenance tools and activities are not controlled, logged, and monitored, accidental or malicious damage through the use of power tools and access may be introduced.

PR.MA-2.description: Remote maintenance of organizational assets is approved, logged, and performed in a manner that prevents unauthorized access
recommendations: Document the process that defines the appropriate procedures for remote maintenance of organizational assets. Document which individuals or vendors are authorized to perform remote maintenance, documenting the work to be performed, establishing remote access to the environment, limiting access to the appropriate information systems, reviewing the work performed, and removing access when it is no longer needed. Implement appropriate controls to support the defined process. Monitor and review to ensure remote access requirements are followed and privileges are not abused.
vulnerability_stmts: If remote maintenance tools and activities are not controlled, logged, and monitored, accidental or malicious damage through the use of power tools and access may be introduced.

PR.PT.name: Protective Technology
PR.PT.description: Technical security solutions are managed to ensure the security and resilience of systems and assets, consistent with related policies, procedures, and agreements.

PR.PT-1.description: Audit/log records are determined, documented, implemented, and reviewed in accordance with policy
recommendations: Define and document which information should be logged by information systems, and take steps to ensure critical functions are logged. Regularly evaluate logs for anomalous activity, with a particular focus on high-value and critical information systems.
vulnerability_stmts: Detailed logs are critical to detect and investigate malicious or suspicious activity. Without logging in place, the organization’s effectiveness is greatly reduced in responding to attacks and investigating the impact.

PR.PT-2.description: Removable media is protected and its use restricted according to policy
recommendations: Utilize policy and procedural restrictions to define how removable media devices are utilized by the organization. Those restrictions may include requiring encryption on all removable media that store sensitive information. Automatically scan removable media connecting to organizational systems for malicious software.
vulnerability_stmts: If removable media is not restricted and protected, the organization is more susceptible to malicious software spreading and data leaks.

PR.PT-3.description: The principle of least functionality is incorporated by configuring systems to provide only essential capabilities
recommendations: Disable any nonessential or insecure functions, ports, and services within information systems. Define appropriate uses for protocols such as Bluetooth, FTP and peer to peer networking that are considered less secure protocols.
vulnerability_stmts: As complexity of the system functions increase, it becomes more difficult to secure and control the system effectively.

PR.PT-4.description: Communications and control networks are protected
recommendations: Control access to organizational networks through appropriate authentication technologies, and protect the network via multi-layered boundary protection mechanisms including: firewalls, wireless access authentication, internet filtering, intrusion prevention, gateway protection, white/blacklisting, encryption tunnels, and similar preventative technologies.
vulnerability_stmts: Without network protections in place such as firewalling and access restriction, attackers and malicious programs will more readily and easily spread to other systems in the organization.

PR.PT-5.description: Mechanisms (e.g., failsafe, load balancing, hot swap) are implemented to achieve resilience requirements in normal and adverse situations
recommendations: Ensure that availability requirements are defined and required capacity is understood. Technical mechanisms (e.g., failsafe, load balancing, hot swap, UPS, etc.) should be in place and sufficient to consistently meet the defined availability requirements for all information systems. Periodically test to ensure availability and resilience technologies and procedures are functioning as efficiently as expected.
vulnerability_stmts: When no failsafes or other resilience mechanisms are in place, disasters and other security events may have a greater negative impact on organizations.

DE.AE.name: Anomalies and Events
DE.AE.description: Anomalous activity is detected and the potential impact of events is understood.

DE.AE-1.description: A baseline of network operations and expected data flows for users and systems is established and managed.
recommendations: Develop and document an understanding of what typical network traffic patterns are including typical traffic volumes, timeframes for access, access locations, and typical functions performed by users within information systems. Employ mechanisms, such as traffic analysis and system log review, to detect deviations from expected usage that may be indicators of compromise.
vulnerability_stmts: If there isn't a well understood baseline of what normal looks like on a network, response and analysis of security events may be less effective.

DE.AE-2.description: Detected events are analyzed to understand attack targets and methods
recommendations: Implement the appropriate processes and mechanisms to determine the type and scope of an attack. Ensure staff are able to accurately determine the type and complete scope of the event, along with the appropriate mitigation strategy.
vulnerability_stmts: Without an attempt to understand the targets and methodology of an attack, response efforts may not be as effective. Focusing on the areas where the attack may have the greatest impact will help minimize damage and contain threats more efficiently.

DE.AE-3.description: Event data are collected and correlated from multiple sources and sensors
recommendations: SIEM

Procure a technology (such as a security information and event management platform) to analyze and mitigate detected events based on alerts from detection systems and methods, and correlate events across multiple sources to determine the full scope of the attack.
vulnerability_stmts: Without a system to correlate events across multiple sources, the organization’s effectiveness is greatly reduced in responding to attacks and investigating the impact.

recommendations: Analyze and assess events based on the sensitivity of data and assets involved to determine impact on the organization. Consistently gather and utilize relevant
information from internal and external resources to improve impact analysis of events.
vulnerability_stmts: During analysis of events, the lack of impact analysis hampers the ability to escalate communications appropriately.

recommendations: Define thresholds and processes for determining the criticality of an incident and determining the appropriate timeframe for mitigation. Document processes so that upon detection, an incident is able to be efficiently categorized and mitigated. Share documentation about thresholds and timeframes with all appropriate parties, including external partners, who have a role in the mitigation of the incident.
vulnerability_stmts: Without incident alert thresholds, security operations analysts can be overwhelmed by false positives and lose sight of important events that should be investigated.

DE.CM.name: Security Continuous Monitoring
DE.CM.description: The information system and assets are monitored to identify cybersecurity events and verify the effectiveness of protective measures.

DE.CM-1.description: The network is monitored to detect potential cybersecurity events
recommendations: Log and regularly examine Activity related to network accounts and infrastructure for indicators of anomalous or unauthorized activity.
vulnerability_stmts: If the network is not monitored to detect cybersecurity events, response to attacks and potential attacks will be delayed and potentially inappropriate. This may lead to higher levels of damage and impact to the organization.

DE.CM-2.description: The physical environment is monitored to detect potential cybersecurity events
recommendations: Utilize human or automated surveillance (cameras and alarms) monitor the physical environment containing high-value systems, sensitive information, or critical infrastructure. Log all access by recording the accessing individual, time of access, and reason for access. Regularly review access logs.
vulnerability_stmts: If the physical environment is not monitored to detect cybersecurity events, response to attacks and potential attacks will be delayed and potentially inappropriate. This may lead to higher levels of damage and impact to the organization.

DE.CM-3.description: Personnel activity is monitored to detect potential cybersecurity events
recommendations: Use automated mechanisms (Security Information and Event Monitor tool or SIEM) to monitor logs and user behavior on all organizational systems and infrastructure. The SIEM should enable information gathered to be analyzed in near real time, and alerts provided for remediation.
vulnerability_stmts: If personnel activity is not monitored to detect cybersecurity events, response to attacks and potential attacks will be delayed and potentially inappropriate. This may lead to higher levels of damage and impact to the organization.

DE.CM-4.genus: Malicious Software Detection - Endpoint Detection and Response
recommendations: Deploy mechanisms to detect malicious code on all organizational systems. Ensure that logs and alerts

are regularly monitored and events are remediated per the defined organizational vulnerability remediation process. Periodically analyze detected events to assess the threat landscape and protection strategies.
vulnerability_stmts: If there is not mechanism in place to detect and respond to malicious code, endpoint infections will be more impactful on the organization in a negative way.

recommendations: Define acceptable uses of mobile code (e.g. Java, JavaScript, ActiveX, Postscript, PDF, Shockwave movies, Flash animations, VB Script, etc.) and develop related
restrictions. Enforce appropriate utilization and restrictions. Detect or prevent (blacklist) mobile code operating outside of organizational requirements.
vulnerability_stmts: When mobile code is not restricted and controlled, mobile code software from a remote host can execute and affect endpoints without explicit interaction or instruction from a user. This may be harmful if the code is malicious or damaging in some way.

DE.CM-6.description: External service provider activity is monitored to detect potential cybersecurity events
recommendations: Use automated mechanisms (SIEM) to monitor logs, traffic, connections, and account behavior on all organizational systems and infrastructure to which external service providers connect or have access. Analyze the information gathered in near real time, and provide alerts to remediate as necessary.
vulnerability_stmts: Service providers are often given temporary elevated privileges to systems in order to maintain or fix them. If this access is not closely logged and monitored, a vendor could maliciously or accidentally introduce vulnerabilities or cause damage.

DE.CM-7.description: Monitoring for unauthorized personnel, connections, devices, and software is performed
recommendations: Use automated mechanisms (SIEM) to monitor connections, logs, user behavior, and device activity on
all organizational systems and infrastructure. Analyze the information gathered in near real time, and provide alerts to remediate as necessary.
vulnerability_stmts: If monitoring is not in place for unauthorized connections, devices, or software, malicious activity could go undetected on the network.

recommendations: Regularly conduct vulnerability scans on discoverable, critical, or high value information systems and infrastructure. Categorize identified vulnerabilities by level of risk to the organization and mitigate accordingly. Track and document the mitigation processes and time to mitigate for all applicable vulnerabilities.
Vulnerability Management Program
vulnerability_stmts: Lack of a regimented cadence of assessing, tracking, and fixing discovered vulnerabilities, the organization leaves multiple weaknesses for an attacker to use to cause damage to the organization.

DE.DP.name: Detection Processes
DE.DP.description: Detection processes and procedures are maintained and tested to ensure awareness of anomalous events.

DE.DP-1.description: Roles and responsibilities for detection are well defined to ensure accountability
recommendations: Identify individuals with the responsibility to perform and monitor threat detection processes and assign defined tasks related to cybersecurity event detection. Implement oversight mechanisms (metrics, steering committee) to ensure activities are performed effectively, accurately, and with integrity.
vulnerability_stmts: Shortage of dedicated personnel for detecting and responding to threats may lead to increased time to detect and mitigate an attack. The gap in assigned staff will increase the impact and damage to the organization in the event of a cybersecurity attack.

DE.DP-2.description: Detection activities comply with all applicable requirements
recommendations: Using an inventory of required controls and regulations, define and document the required detection activities and implement protocols to perform those activities across all systems in the environment.
vulnerability_stmts: Without a complete and accurate inventory of regulatory requirements or organization defined requirements, detection mechanisms may not be implemented appropriately to meet compliance needs.

recommendations: Assess detection practices to verify existing controls and processes are functioning as expected, as well as identify existing coverage gaps and inefficiencies of processes. Periodically assess detection mechanisms and processes with a third-party partner through methods such as penetration testing or stress testing.
vulnerability_stmts: If detection mechanisms are not regularly tested and verified effective, the tools may fail during an attack when you need the detection the most.

recommendations: Communicate information related to detected cybersecurity events to those staff responsible for

mitigation, response, communication, or to other stakeholders who might be otherwise affected. Regularly share a list of detected cybersecurity events, their impact, and the mitigation that occurred with organizational leaders. Apply the information to enhance the organization’s security posture. Periodically review these communication processes to confirm appropriate stakeholders are receiving the appropriate information.
vulnerability_stmts: If event detection information does not get communicated to the appropriate parties, response efforts may get impeded.

recommendations: Regularly evaluate detection processes and related information and adjust practices to address gaps and inefficiencies in the detection process. Prioritize areas of highest risk for improvement. Periodically use outside partners to evaluate detection processes to provide recommendations for processes enhancement.
vulnerability_stmts: Devoid of testing the effectivness of detection mechanisms, improvement opportunities may be missed and lead to stagnation with the tool.

RS.RP.name: Response Planning
RS.RP.description: Response processes and procedures are executed and maintained, to ensure response to detected cybersecurity incidents.

RS.RP-1.description: Response plan is executed during or after an incident
recommendations: Define and document a cybersecurity incident response plan. Use tabletop exercises or response testing environments to regularly test processes, procedures, and supporting technology to ensure the plan can function as intended. Update processes, procedures, and supporting

technology as the environment or requirements change, or failures occur during plan execution. Develop incident response metrics related to frequency of incident occurrence, success of treatment, and efficiency of response.
vulnerability_stmts: The lack of planning and testing of response and recovery plans leads to inappropriate and lengthier response and recovery events. Ultimately, this leads to increased damage and impact to the organization. Without testing the plans that have been built, the organization may be blind to gaps in communication or other parts of the process that may lengthen or impact efforts to restore normal operations.

RS.CO.name: Communications
RS.CO.description: Response activities are coordinated with internal and external stakeholders (e.g. external support from law enforcement agencies).

RS.CO-1.description: Personnel know their roles and order of operations when a response is needed
RS.CO-1.genus: Cybersecurity Responsibility Assignment and Documentation - Incident Response
recommendations: Define key roles and responsibilities (incident leader, incident coordinator, incident communicator, executive responders) in the Incident Response Plan. Train personnel and provide copies of organizational response plans that contain their roles and responsibilities related to incident response. Gather core members of the incident response team periodically to examine roles and responsibilities, and make any updates as the environment or requirements change. Distribute updates and reminders to all organizational staff with a role in incident response.
https://www.ibm.com/security/data-breach
vulnerability_stmts: During a cybersecurity incident, speed and accuracy of response actions are critical. If personnel are unsure of their role in the response process or lack clarity about order of operations, costly mistakes can be made.

RS.CO-2.description: Incidents are reported consistent with established criteria
recommendations: Define a process for staff and other stakeholders to report potential security incidents for analysis. Communicate the process and associated reporting requirements to appropriate staff at the time of development.
vulnerability_stmts: Management and authorities may not have appropriate information to take action if information about incidents are not reported.

RS.CO-3.description: Information is shared consistent with response plans
recommendations: Define a process to meet identified statutory and regulatory information sharing requirements. Define criteria for information that may be shared related to security incidents, including what types of information may be shared and with which primary stakeholders, outside of statutory and regulatory requirements. The external stakeholders may include the general public or local community for example.
vulnerability_stmts: Authorities and other key stakeholders may not have appropriate information if the incident response plan doesn't detail requirements for sharing certain information in the event of certain incidents.

RS.CO-4.description: Coordination with stakeholders occurs consistent with response plans
recommendations: Define a list of internal and external stakeholders that will need to be directly or indirectly involved with response activities. Document a process that details the level of involvement necessary and the point in the response at which time the stakeholder will need to be engaged by the Incident Response Team. Ensure staff are aware of how and when to coordinate with both internal and external stakeholders in the event of a security incident.
vulnerability_stmts: Stakeholders may not receive the proper communication during an incident without defined criteria for contact and a complete list of all stakeholders.

RS.CO-5.description: Voluntary information sharing occurs with external stakeholders to achieve broader cybersecurity situational awareness
recommendations: Define criteria for information that may be shared with the community (such as through information sharing consortiums) related to security incidents, including what types of information may be shared and with which outside stakeholders. Make recipients of voluntary information sharing aware of what the organization considers appropriate use of that information.
vulnerability_stmts: Without defined criteria for sharing information with external stakeholders, too little or too much information may get shared about security incidents.

RS.AN.name: Analysis
RS.AN.description: Analysis is conducted to ensure effective response and support recovery activities.

RS.AN-1.description: Notifications from detection systems are investigated
recommendations: Train staff members to be aware of the detection systems alerts they are responsible for investigating and to investigate alerts appropriately based on the type and severity of the alert.
Utilize automated mechanisms to aggregate, correlate and analyze security notifications from detection systems.
vulnerability_stmts: Without defined processes and responsibilities to monitor notifications from detection tools, incidents can spread before the incident gets detected.

RS.AN-2.description: The impact of the incident is understood
recommendations: Establish the capability as part of the incident response process to determine the scope (e.g. systems, data, users, system performance, etc.) of the incident and quantify the impact the incident had on the organization holistically by using data collected as part of a business impact analysis study.
vulnerability_stmts: In the absence of a business impact analysis, the true impact of an incident may be difficult or impossible to identify. This may lead to response actions that are not commenserate for the type or severity of the incident.

recommendations: Define and document steps to preserve systems, logs, and other sources of evidence related to an incident, in the event they are needed for forensic investigation. Define incident types and situations where forensic investigation is required and establish relationships for the investigation to be conducted by forensic experts. Document and train relevant staff that the preference during an incident is to leave an affected system turned on, but not connected to the network or to the internet.
vulnerability_stmts: Without a well-defined order of operations during an incident, important information supporting investigation of impact and damage may be missed or lost.

RS.AN-4.description: Incidents are categorized consistent with response plans
recommendations: Define categories and severity rankings of incidents to be utilized for identifying incident response actions. Categories of incidents may include, for example, malfunctions due to design/implementation errors and omissions, targeted malicious attacks, and untargeted malicious attacks. Assign appropriate incident response reactions to the defined categories and severity rankings by using runbooks to define steps for specific events. Each severity rating should also have assigned tasks such as communication and coordination with specific stakeholders.
vulnerability_stmts: During a cybersecurity incident, speed and accuracy of response actions are critical. If personnel are unsure of how categories of incidents and severity levels affect the response process or lack clarity about order of operations, costly mistakes can be made.

RS.AN-5.description: Processes are established to receive, analyze and respond to vulnerabilities disclosed to the organization from internal and external sources (e.g. internal testing, security bulletins, or security researchers)
recommendations: Establish a process to receive vulnerability alerts from internal and external sources. Additionally, develop a process to categorize the severity of vulnerabilities and respond accordingly.
vulnerability_stmts: Vulnerabilities can get left open for internal and external threats without a program to manage the vulnerability's discovery, prioritization, and treatment.

RS.MI.name: Mitigation
RS.MI.description: Activities are performed to prevent expansion of an event, mitigate its effects, and resolve the incident.

recommendations: Identify various containment strategies that are appropriate for the environment, such as system disconnection, limiting access, rerouting traffic, network disconnection, disabling functions, etc. Map incident types to the appropriate containment strategies. Ensure that containment strategies detail methods of preserving forensic data such as volatile memory and logs that may be overwritten in the event of a system shutdown.
vulnerability_stmts: The incident may spread to other environments, including critical systems, without a defined containment strategy for specific incident types.

recommendations: Identify mitigation strategies that are appropriate for the environment, such as rotation of credentials, removal of accounts, patching vulnerabilities, etc. Additionally, map incident types to the appropriate mitigation strategies by identifying likely threats and assigning controls to mitigate damage. Using offline backup methodologies to combat the threat of data loss from ransomware is an example of the mapping of control strategies to a specific threat.
vulnerability_stmts: Without mitigation efforts that are appropriate for the incident category, the cause of the incident may get reintroduced during the recovery phase.

RS.MI-3.description: Newly identified vulnerabilities are mitigated or documented as accepted risks
recommendations: Continuously acquire, assess, and take action on new information in order to identify vulnerabilities, remediate, and minimize the window of opportunity for attackers.
Implement automated scanning tools against all systems on a weekly basis.
Deploy automated patch management and software update tools.
Routinely monitor event logs.
SIEM/Vuln Mgmt.
vulnerability_stmts: If vulnerabilities that lead to an incident are not remediated, the incident may recur.

RS.IM.name: Improvements
RS.IM.description: Organizational response activities are improved by incorporating lessons learned from current and previous detection/response activities.

recommendations: Review incidents and how the response process was applied to determine any enhancements that are necessary for the plan. Some factors to consider are: efficiency, communication, incident identification, containment strategy, mitigation strategy, prevention strategy, etc. Additionally, during the incident response process, keep records of key events, process activities applied, and potential enhancements to better inform the response improvement discussion. Use the information collected and discussed to develop incident response metrics to quantify improvement.
vulnerability_stmts: With no review and analysis of potential lessons learned from an incident, it is likely that repeated mistakes will occur during the next incident.

recommendations: Update response strategies based on outcomes from incident reviews that occur immediately following an incident.
vulnerability_stmts: If response plans and strategies aren't updated to include the lessons that have been learned in previous incidents or exercises, it is likely that mistakes will be repeated in the next incident.

RC.RP.name: Recovery Planning
RC.RP.description: Recovery processes and procedures are executed and maintained to ensure restoration of systems or assets affected by cybersecurity incidents.

RC.RP-1.description: Recovery plan is executed during or after a cybersecurity incident
recommendations: Develop a Disaster Recovery plan that addresses recovery of security controls in the event of a disaster. Ensure that the plan also addresses the need to initiate recovery procedures only after the eradication phase of the response lifecycle is complete.
vulnerability_stmts: The lack of planning and testing of recovery processes leads to inappropriate and lengthier response and recovery events. Ultimately, this leads to increased damage and impact to the organization. Without testing the plans that have been built, the organization may be blind to gaps in communication or other parts of the process that may lengthen or impact efforts to restore normal operations.

RC.IM.name: Improvements
RC.IM.description: Recovery planning and processes are improved by incorporating lessons learned into future activities.

recommendations: Review incidents and how the recovery process was applied to determine any enhancements that are necessary for the disaster recovery plan. Some factors to consider are efficiency, communication, incident identification, containment strategy, mitigation strategy, prevention strategy, etc. Additionally, during the recovery process, keep records of key events, process activities applied, and potential enhancements to better inform the recovery improvement discussion. Use the information collected and discussed to develop disaster recovery metrics to quantify improvement.
vulnerability_stmts: With no review and analysis of potential lessons learned from an event, it is likely that repeated mistakes will occur during the next disaster.

recommendations: Update recovery strategies based on outcomes from event reviews that occur immediately following a disaster.
vulnerability_stmts: If recovery plans and strategies aren't updated to include the lessons that have been learned in previous events or exercises, it is likely that mistakes will be repeated in the next disaster.

RC.CO.name: Communications
RC.CO.description: Restoration activities are coordinated with internal and external parties (e.g. coordinating centers, Internet Service Providers, owners of attacking systems, victims, other CSIRTs, and vendors).

recommendations: Develop a strategy and guidelines for managing public relations which includes assigned roles, acceptable communication language, approvals required. Establish communication templates for common events to ensure quick dissemination of accurate information.
vulnerability_stmts: The absence of public relations management leaves the organization open to increase reputational damage as a result of an incident.

RC.CO-2.description: Reputation is repaired after an incident
recommendations: Develop a strategy and guidelines for managing public relations which includes assigned roles, acceptable communication language, approvals required. Establish communication templates for common events to ensure quick dissemination of accurate information.
Proactively communicate appropriate facts to repair reputational damage. Consider consulting with a public relations firm.
vulnerability_stmts: The absence of public relations management leaves the organization open to increase reputational damage as a result of an incident.

RC.CO-3.description: Recovery activities are communicated to internal and external stakeholders as well as executive and management teams
recommendations: Define a list of internal and external stakeholders that will need to be directly or indirectly involved with response activities. Document a process that details the level of involvement necessary and the point in the response at which time the stakeholder will need to be engaged by the Disaster Recovery Team. Ensure staff are aware of how and when to coordinate with both internal and external stakeholders in the event of a recovery incident.
vulnerability_stmts: Without defined criteria for sharing information with external stakeholders, too little or too much information may get shared about security incidents.
